required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Electroporation for Cancer Treatment Real World Registry
clinical_study.official_title: Electroporation for Cancer Treatment Real World Registry

brief_summary.textblock: This registry aims to assess real-world long-term disease outcomes for patients treated using reversible electroporation and a chemotherapeutic or calcium; in particular tumour response rates and recurrence rates. The study also aims to characterise side effects and the occurrence of Adverse Events and their relationship to the treatment.

primary_outcome.description: Safety evaluation will be performed via continuous assessment of safety parameters by reviewing events as they arise. The investigation will be put on hold if unacceptable safety issues are outstanding. Adverse Events (AE) and Serious Adverse Events (SAE) will be evaluated and graded according to Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE)

secondary_outcome.measure: Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumours (RECIST)
secondary_outcome.description: A response evaluation will be conducted at standard of care follow up

secondary_outcome.measure: Modified FACE-Q evaluation for Skin Cancers
secondary_outcome.description: Cosmesis evaluation will be recorded for skin cancers at standard of care follow up

study_pop.textblock: This study is a single arm, observational medical device registry designed to establish the efficacy and safety of treating solid tumours with reversible electroporation. ePORE, CUTIS and EndoVE are CE marked and are currently being used in the treatment of patients with solid tumours. This medical device registry will enable the collection of anonymised data which will enable the analysis and publication of high quality data to continuously support the efficacy and safety of these devices.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any patient who has been treated using Calcium Electroporation
- Any patient who has been treated using Electrochemotherapy
- Patients must be mentally capable of understanding the information given
- Patients must give written informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- None
